description: The award-winning Elder Scrolls saga goes online! In The Elder Scrolls Online, experience one connected world and stay up-to-date with everything your friends are doing in one of the most socially enabled games ever. Whether you play alone or with your friends, the game’s innovative combat system allows you to focus on action and tactics, not the UI. Use any weapon at any time, no matter your class, and customize your abilities to play the way you want as you uncover the mysteries of Tamriel and seek heroic quests on your own terms. Explore the far reaches of Skyrim, the mysterious lands of Morrowind, the sprawling metropolis of Daggerfall and beyond. The choices you make, from the alliance you join to the battles you fight, will shape your destiny and the world of Tamriel.
reviewText: Ok, I have waited a long while, and experienced much of this game, from Beta to today, and am finally writing a review. I have a love hate relationship with the Elder Scrolls games. They are wonderfully imaginative and open ended, but also riddled with bugs.This is not your typical MMO, you will not be constrained to any class restrictions, and they really did a fantastic job of letting you play any type of character how you want. Heavy armor mage tank, no problem. One can get really creative with how they approach the game. With this aspect, the game is a homerun!Crafting is well done and varied as well, I craft more items than I buy. There is no global auction house, instead you must use guilds, and in turn become more self reliant. Another homerun!Graphics ( with a good card) are awesome. This game runs very smoothly, and is hands down the most optimized MMO I have ever played. They did a truly incredible and amazing job. Sound is great as well.Questing and combat are better than many other MMOs, questing isnt kill x amount of mobs and report back. Combat is much more interactive than other mmos where ya just hit a button. It is fun.Exploration is fun as well, a lot of people seem to knock it, but I think they did it well, considering its an MMo and not a regular elder scrolls game.If you are a fan of elder scrolls and MMos, you will love this game, if you want elder scrolls, and are not into MMos, you will probably hate it. If you are a fan of MMos, there is a good chance you will like ESO. It is a great game, when you can be immersed in it. But that is the catch, you cant really get immersed in it.Inventory is brutal. Awful. You have a single shared bank for all of your characters. You don't get a lot of bank slots, and upgrading is expensive and doesn't yield much more storage. It become a juggling act of logging in and out of alts to store crafting mats. It is so unnecessary. Its just Zenimax being cheap and not paying for more sever storage. This is one of the games most glaring faults!Now the downside....Bots and gold spammers are running the show. It was bad at launch. real bad. impossible at times even. expect to see bots camped at bosses. expect to be constantly harassed by gold spammers via zone chat and mail. While there is an ignore list, you will spend more time playing the ignore player minigame, rather than ESO. To make matters worse, you are limited to 100 ignored players, which fills up very fast.Personally I believe it is ESO employees that are the gold spammers. they could have easily resolved the issues by now, but they haven't. It has gotten better, but not good enough. They have changed what he gold spammers can type into chat boxes, but are not actually removing them, and they make reporting them time consuming and long winded. Why isn't there a moderator in each zone monitoring the chat and solving the problem right there and then?So while you are being bombarded with gold spammers, quests and combat are going to start to break. sometimes its a simple fix like logging in and out. However, it is hard to get immersed in the game when quests constantly break and some gold spammer just wont quit. for me this is when the frustration sets in, and I ask myself, why am I paying for this.Customer service is hands down the absolute worst. Nonexistent. If you have a problem, too bad. All you can do is send an in game mail to CS, they will eventually get to it, but don't expect any immediate help. They even banned me by mistake, offered nothing for my lost time, and never explained why or how I was banned. When I pressed the issue and asked for an explanation they just ignored me. Now 99% of my issues are just ignored. I don't know if they are too busy, or just don't care, I am guessing both.I also run a very large guild, and every day i see players leaving and not returning to the game. It is a lot. This game has potential, but not too many people are sticking around and waiting for it.All in all, is it fun ...yes. Is it well done... kind of, certain parts are so polished and optimized, then certain parts are so lazy and incomplete it makes you scratch your head.Is it worth $15 a month? hard to say. In its current state I am leaning towards no. mind you it has some serious MMO game changing potential, but I am kind of doubtful it is going to be reached. The real deal-breaker for me is the inability to control the gold-spammers and bots. They are relentless in this game and just running wild. its like paying for commercials, I can't stand it.While I do like the game, I also regret buying the multi month subscription. I could deal with the bugs, but I cant deal with bugs and constant gold spammers hounding you in general chat, mail, and guildinvites.If they cant resolve the issues quickly, expect this game to be F2P soon, no one is gonna pay a sub for long in its current state. While I suppose gold spammers are paying customers too, pretty soon they will be the only customers.EDIT: ERROR 301 So I havent been able to log into the game for some time because of some server error. Customer service has just wasted my time with wild goose chases and chores for me to do on client side. This product seems to only get worse with each patch. Oh, and CS doesnt really work on the weekend, so yeah, if ya have a problem on friday, you are stuck till at least monday. I really, really regret buying this game.

summary: Believe the hype, this game delivers
reviewText: Believe the hype because this game really is a work of art.. its a very unique game, its probably the best story type of game I've ever played.  I was waiting for the graphics to get worse because in the beginning when you are dropped off at a lighthouse I thought the graphics were amazing, but the entire game is like that graphic wise.. you can tell a lot of detail was put into this game.I give the game 4 1/2 stars for being a little linear, meaning not many side missions.. it would be nice if you could explore more in the world in the sky, but a lot of it is just going from objective to objective which don't get me wrong follows a great story, but it could use more exploring options.  I think that Dishonored was a little like this, as far as being linear from objective to objective, and Irrational games also made Dishonored.. but it really doesn't take away a large part of the quality of the game, it would just be nice to be able to explore more I guess... of course this comes from somebody who beat almost every objective in Skyrim, an open world game which is different then this and I knew that going into it... its still a solid 4 1/2 star game and it will probably be the best game of the year, I was never into the Grand Theft Auto games much, that game is coming out this fall but honestly the way this game is made with this quality it should be considered the best game of the year.. you can see now why it was pushed back a couple times, the developers really wanted to make it shine and they did, this game deserves your time.

description: The island of Banoi is a lush, tropical paradise in the South Pacific where its flagship Royal Palms Resort serves as the ultimate getaway for vacationers with money to burn. However, all good things must soon come to an end - and the picturesque resort falls into madness, carnage and chaos after a mysterious and contagious zombie outbreak claims its once peaceful atmosphere. Cut off from the rest of the world, only four individuals who strangely find themselves immune to zombification have the power to protect the remaining survivors from the horrors of the island, to discover what's really going on and find a way to escape before their own fatal ends.    Gameplay HighlightsIn keeping with an atmosphere of desperation and survival by any means, Dead Island focuses on serious,first-person actiongameplay with a close-quarter,immersive melee focus.Dead Island'sseamless 4 player co-op multiplayerseeks to provide the most immersive multiplayer experience to date. Players can drop in and out of each other's games at any time with no loss of progress as well as the ability to continue on alone or with others.Withthousands of weapons in-gameto collect, from simple wooden bats to fire-axes to heavy rifles, Dead Island is a collector's dream. This in combination with Dead Island'sweapon customization systemwill enable the player to craft the ultimate weapon to ensure their survival.The ability to enhance and develop your character usingRPG-like elementsincluding an XP/leveling system and un-lockable skill trees put the power in your hands to create and play a unique protagonist.Dead Island's damage system gives an unprecedented visual detail of the effects of each attack on enemies pushing the boundaries of visualized gore.With anopen-world setting, Banoi is filled to the brim with things to do and objectives to tackle, allowing a fresh way to advance both the characters and story at the same time and providing for endless replay value.
reviewText: There are two types of zombie stories: the kind where emotion, realism and idealism are on display causing you to make moral choices with real consequences (think the Walking Dead episodes on Xbox/ Steam) and then there are the massive hoards of zombies that only exist for your dismembership pleasure where your only goal is to make bigger weapons to decapitate and destroy your unfortuntate fellow humans. This game is the second one. Which totally sucks considering the emotional trailer that was released ahead of time.If you've played Dead Rising 2 you've played this game except this game is on an Island (city, resort, jungle) instead of a mall (mall, city). You have tons of gofer missions where your job is basically to go from here to there and back again for a few bucks or a prize. Rinse and repeat. This is a cheap way to make the game longer and add so-called depth to the game. But is it really adding anything when you get quests like this one: a (fully adult looking) woman (in a bikini) talks like a baby and asks you to save her teddy bear from a bungalow nearby. WTH?!Some other noticeable defects in the game:-You collect money all over the island then use that money to upgrade and repair weapons. Who you are giving the money to is not explained. Why you would pay in currency that is defunct to fix weapons doesnt make sense. Why not have to collect parts to fix your weapons? Money?-The "story" doesn't exist. This game isn't touted as being a pure survival story like Dawn of the Dead or something where your only goal is to survive. This game is all about moving towards some kind of goal. The problem is that you don't know the goal for most of the game. Instead you'll spend hours and hours collecting juice from a gas station, fixing a kick butt armored car A-Team style (and then never using it again), checking out a downed helecopter only to find that you really only found a bunch more mini quests.-The enemies rank up with you so no matter how awesome you get you never really see the benefits of your new abilities other than in the new ways you can kill the zombies. On the other hand, you never are too far below the ability of any enemies so killing them basically becomes a button masher without worrying about skills or rank ups or anything.-Because cool weapons (valued at maybe $500) cost $1000 or more to repair if you use them you have to either 1) use a bunch of crap weapons because you don't want to bust your awesome one, or 2) spend a boat load of time finding money.-Cut scenes sometimes show all four of the playable characters but you never meet the other three characters or play along side them unless you play online. Why not simply make custom cut scenes for each character?-Zombies that explode, that bulldoze you (rams), and that are toxic may be interesting in the game but don't (in my opinion) fit in to the zombie story. Maybe there is one huge zombie in the world that happens to be in a straight jacket and tries to kill by running you over. I get that. But 50 giant zombies all in straight jackets in one city? Overuse of the boss. Some zombies could have become toxic if they worked at a waste plant or something but then they'd all be at the plant not all over the place. Why a zombie would blow up (ala Halo) doesn't make sense.For all its faults the game is a simple diversion that you may enjoy. I did for about 10 hours before I realized nothing new was coming. Now that the game is super cheap it may be worth it to you. For me, I'd have been very disappointed if I had paid more than $5- 10 for this game.

When I heard that the one had a redesigned controller, I cringed.  While I had never loved the 360 controller, I had grown very accustomed to it.  I was very worried that this new controller would feel awkward in my hands.I am glad to report that the new controller is different in good ways, and the same in all the right ways.The new triggers and bumpers have a great feel and are slightly more ergonomic.  The edge of the trigger has been eased where your finger wraps around making it a bit more comfortable for extended game sessions.  The trigger has slightly less resistance than the old trigger, which I found acceptable, my son is not as big a fan.  The sticks feel a bit more precise, but more than anything they feel the same which is a good thing in my book.The most obvious change to the controller is the battery pack.  The battery pack has been replaced with a AA battery compartment.  No longer is there a wart on the backside of the controller, which makes it a bit more comfortable.  The batteries are a bit more awkward to swap in a rush than a battery pack was, but it is still very manageable.The new controller is very slightly heavier at 9 7/8 oz vs 9 1/2 oz.The dpad is now recessed, but feels right.The location of the X, back and start buttons is a little awkward if you are used to the old controller.  Thankfully these are not often used in the heat of the moment and they are generally close enough to where they were to find them by feel.Checkout my pictures to see the difference in the trigger.

The future of the worlddepends on Kameo who must capture harness and unleash a wide assortment ofmonsters to rescue three of her Elemental Ancestors and destroy the Dark TrollKing who threatens the pla and its wildlife. Kameo will be granted the powerto transform into incredible monsters but they must be honed to their maximumcapacity as she makes her way through a world bursting with strange life andbreathtaking sights.Product Features Transform in real-time into a dazzling array of incredible monsters each with its own fantastical strengths and fighting styles Employ 10 elemental monsters from the five Elements of Power - Plant Water Rock Ice and Fire Use roughly 30 unique attack and exploration abilities -- the innovative and sophisticated bat scoring system will track players' effectiveness to outmaneuver fight and destroy the enemy Use monsters to tunnel underground climb ice walls jump ramps blow up obstacles -- even for unlocking new worlds solving environment puzzles and avoiding obstructions traps and enemies Explore a vast and magical world filled with lush environments wondrous creatures clever puzzles and big challenges
reviewText: If you like any mario or cartoonish adventure game then this is definately worth looking at. This has to be one of the most beautifully animated games ive ever seen, in the beginning of the game you are in an elf kingdom wandering about, and the detail everthing down to the blades of grass is astonishing. I played the first hour of the game just wandering arounding looking at this highly detailed enviroment, this must have cost some serious artist hours. But enough about looks, kameo herself only has 2 moves one is sprawling out her wings and hovering around which is the fastest way to travel and the other is a backflip kick which is her only attack, but the fun starts when you get the characters that you can morph into, each has their own abilties and you can upgrade them with fruits that you can get in several different ways, ranging from helping some poor tree man get rid of the pests in his house, to winning them in side games that show your skill with the warrior trainer, also when you start getting more characters you can chain the morphing and the moves together for really cool effects, in some places you have to, bottom line a beautfully rendered game, with a decnt story and fun gameplay, not a bad deal at the lowered price.

There's not much to say about this game. If you played many First Person Shooters this will be last on your list.  This offers nothing new compare to the first two halo's.  If you move around a lot and avoid enemy fire you don't really have to use cover, making this more of a run and gun game or a walk and gun game because your character has no running abilities. The cut scenes are not really that interesting.  there are about 9 missions in this game,  If you are new to Halo or haven't played Halo 2 I recommend playing it which has more variety, longer game play and gives you the chance to play as the enemy as well. You'll get a feel for the story and understand it better.  When Playing it on the 360 you will feel like the graphics are a little outdated but you'll get use to it quick. you'll get more of a halo experience.

summary: Grand Theft Auto is pure junk
reviewText: This game is just flat out horrible.  If you want a game that is fun to play over and over again, and want great graphics and everything else you should look elsewhere.  There is no variety in this game whatsoever.

I live near the real "Vice City" and driving down what could only be South Beach, in a video game, was very surreal. If your fimilar with the GTA series then you know these games are not for easly offended folk. If you are new to the series then I can't think of a better game to kick it off with (unless you are easly offended). I can only play this game when my wife is not home or asleep. The graphics are fantastic, the game play is fantastic and the go anywhere, do anything aspect is the most appealing part (especially for you explorer types). The music and radio stations are extremely entertaining. If you are a product of the 80's, then the music will make you feel all warm and fuzzy. The setting and story lines are right out of Miami Vice, but from the bad guys point of view. There is even a little tribute to Scar Face in the game, if you know where to look (exploration will eventually lead you there, or the faster route of consulting a game guide).The good: Game play, replayability, multible story lines that can be followed at your own pace.The bad: Every character in the game, even the police.The ugly: Tommy Vercetti

description: Batman: Arkham Origins features an expanded Gotham City and introduces an original prequel storyline set several years before the events of Batman: Arkham Asylum and Batman: Arkham City, the first two critically acclaimed games of the franchise; Taking place before the rise of Gotham City's most dangerous criminals, the game showcases a young and unrefined Batman as he faces a defining moment in his early career as a crime fighter that sets his path to becoming the Dark Knight; As the story unfolds, players will meet many important characters for the first time and forge key relationships
reviewText: It feels like I'm having Déjà vu when I'm exploring Gotham because if you played Arkham City, it looks exactly-the-same-thing. There's barely anything "brand new" in this game.Despite the feeling of being lost in a flashback, just like Arkham City this game is addicting for me. (I always play on normal) Strange how the bosses here have more difficulty than A.C. which makes it frustrating and fun at the same time. I have no problem with the controls, there's no glitches, and the voice acting is great.(My only complaint)  I do love the Joker, but I wish someone can make a Batman game where he's not so much the main villain all the time. I get it, Batman and Joker are yin and yang-they can't live without each other. However, there are more interesting villains in the series that I would love to learn more about like Mr. Freeze, Black Mask, Deathstroke, etc.If you played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City like me, it will feel like Déjà vu but for those who haven't-this is a fun game.

description: Welcome to Redview County, where a street-racing rivalry between cops and racers never stops as both sides compete in an all-out war to take over the social, local and national media and earn the best cars, mods and technology. Risk Everything. Trust No One.
reviewText: This was a gift for my son who loves car racing games. This game has great graphics and lots of cars to unlock. He has had alot of fun playing this game. A great title to pick up if your looking for some good Xbox One games. I would recommend Need For Speed Rivals..

summary: Top notch headphones from a company you can trust
reviewText: This "Phantom" version of the Ghosts headset is one of the best sets of headphones you can buy at this price point.  With a perfect and fluid mixture of comfort, sound, capability, and wireless compatibility, you cannot do any better than the Phantom Ghost headset.I've used these with both the PS3 and Xbox 360 with simple and outstanding results.  First thing to take note of is these are bluetooth and wireless making them stand out from their brethren versions, "Spectre" and "Shadow".  I had no issues setting this headset up on both systems, and they worked perfectly right out of the box with minimal hassle.  It has eight different sound settings, all presenting a unique twist on whatever your favorite audio preferences might be.  Like mic is outstanding, and among the best I've ever used with a video game headset.  It has several settings allowing you to focus on more of the in-game sounds, or you can turn down the ambience and tune-in to others and chat more.  Either way, it's a perfect level of volume no matter which you prefer.I've examined the bluetooth function with my Mac Mini, iPhone 4, and iPad 3, and have experienced perfect results with pretty stunning sound quality.  These headphones will work for you like a charm if you choose to use them to listen to music on your computer should you choose to do so.  Granted, the sound won't be quite as stellar as when you use them with a game on your console, but I have to say these headphones sound almost just as good as a 300 dollar pair of studio monitor headphones that I use on a regular basis.Rarely have I used a headset that's better across the board for this price, and for the current sale going on (these are $220 as of December 31st, 2013), I can't recommend these highly enough.  Buy yet another quality product from Turtle Beach!  I'll be using these for years to come!

description: The feisty little adolescent dragon is back in a sequel that is far superior to the  original. Both Spyro fans and those who didn't play the first game will revel in the  exploratory greatness that isSpyro: Ripto's Rage. Gone are the impossible tasks,  unbeatable enemies, and fragmented game flow. This game sports superior controls, more  colorful and faster graphics, a tighter story, achievable goals, and plenty of gameplay  variety.Don't be fooled by Spyro's cuteness--this isn't a kid's-only game. With multiple goals  and side quests, a fantastic soundtrack by ex-Police band member Stewart Copeland, and  a veneer of understated humor,Spyro: Ripto's Rageis highly addictive. The  playfulness of the main character comes through in the exploration of the otherworldly  levels using the new moves, including super high jumps, rapid underwater swimming,  and extended flight and hovering maneuvers.Determined explorers are always rewarded--sometimes with an ice hockey match or other  sub-game, sometimes with riches enough to learn a new move or uncover a new area.  Simply put,Spyro: Ripto's Rageis one of the best action/adventure games for the  system. Despite the fact that this game is a sequel, it manages to bring a fresh new look  and feel to PlayStation gaming.--Jeff YoungPros:Massive, fun levels are completely navigableCute and quirky sense of humor will appeal to all agesResponsive controls are an extension of Spyro's upbeat and exacting personalityCons:Camera angles can be problematic, but are completely adjustable
reviewText: Spyro's first adventure was a groundbreaking experience that took place inside a giant world filled with colorful, breathtaking beauty.  It was *awesome* the way the game encouraged you to roam around many graphically-appealing worlds searching for gems and dragons.  Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage proves to be an even BIGGER journey.I honestly didn't think it was possible to surpass the original Spyro game.  It was truly one of the greatest adventure games on the Playstation.  I can only find a couple VERY minor problems with Ripto's Rage.  Let's get them out of the way:- I think the biggest problem is the fact that, once again, the up and down buttons on the directional pad are *still* reversed.  This means, for example, when you go underwater in one of the water levels, you have to hit the Up button to swim down, and the Down button to swim up.  There's a couple other places in the game where the controls are reversed, too.  As far as I know there's NO way to change it to normal.  None of this may seem like a big deal but there's certain obstacles in the game that require you to move quickly through the water, and you want *everything* to be as perfect as possible while you swim to your destination, but thanks to the controls, it won't be easy.  Personally, I've never been able to adjust to it- every so often I will forget that the up and down buttons are reversed when I enter a water or flying stage, so I might swim or fly STRAIGHT into an enemy.  It's mind-boggling to me why the game creators haven't corrected it, or at the very least, gave the player an option to change it.- I find it slightly disappointing that, this time around, every stage has exactly 400 gems.  In the original, each stage had a different amount of gems for you to locate, which made Spyro's first adventure seem like more of a mysterious guessing game.  Not really complaining, though.- A TON of cutscenes are included in Ripto's Rage.  You can skip over them if you want, but I'm amazed that EVERY level has a cutscene in the beginning of a stage and another cutscene after you successfully complete the stage.  Don't worry, Ripto's Rage is still a huge game, maybe even bigger than the original.  In other words, the cutscenes don't suck up all the space on the disc.  Ignoring the cutscenes you STILL have a lengthy game.- This brings us to the next minor problem: the reason we have so many cutscenes is because each stage has a different odd-looking creature living in it, and these creatures (who happen to speak English very well) always want to discuss with Spyro the problems inside their world that they'd like you to fix for them.  Just the fact that EVERY stage features a different talking creature is both a good and bad thing.  A player might think Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage is throwing in TOO MUCH and therefore, you may assume you need to try and remember all the characters you come across in order to follow a story (which isn't true because once you complete a stage, most of the time you never see that character again, so please do NOT worry about having to follow along to any kind of complex storyline).  BUT, on the other hand, all sorts of wild-looking talking friendly creatures communicating with Spyro makes the game THAT much more adventurous.Those are the only complaints I can find, and when you think about it, those are pointless complaints because the game does so many things right.I honestly believe the challenge has been increased significantly in Spyro's second adventure.  Instead of three or four dragons scattered throughout each stage waiting for you to find and rescue, you now have to search for three or four bonus games per stage and you HAVE to successfully complete most of them, which would be an extremely positive thing EXCEPT for the fact that a small handful of these bonus games are REALLY hard to complete.Each time you complete a bonus game you receive an orb.  There's 64 orbs in the game total, and to reach the final boss, you're required to find 40 of them.  In my opinion, probably no more than 10 bonus games are impossibly hard so you SHOULD be able to go through the stages, collect 40 orbs, and beat the game.  Just don't expect to get all 64 orbs because, again, some of those bonus games are difficult.I'm not knocking the bonus games.  After all, it's more interesting to tackle a creative and exciting bonus game than to simply walk up to a frozen dragon and rescue him, like in the original.  In Spyro 2 you don't know WHAT kind of bonus game you'll encounter, which makes the game overall one notch better than the original.  To give a few examples of the bonus games you play: one of them has you playing hockey on ice where you have two minutes to make five goals, another bonus has you trying to quickly burn eight dangerous dragons before they eat the good guys (don't even ask me WHAT these good guys are supposed to be- let's just say they're friendly people that really love you!) another bonus stage has you swimming through rings.  A whole bunch of creative, interesting bonus games await you.  Even if you lose at some of them, you will want to try them again because they're so much fun.People who are familiar with the original might be confused when they reach the end of the game and realize that they only explored three worlds.  The original game featured five worlds, however, the three worlds in Ripto's Rage feature more stages.  So it balances out.The graphics are *exactly* the same as the original.  I can't find a single improvement, or at least, anything different.  The exact same graphic engine.  Oh, and thankfully the creators remembered that very important option to change the camera angle to "active".  VERY important!Stewart Copeland from the rock band the Police returns and succeeds with another fantastic soundtrack.  Another all-around excellent job.My favorite thing about this game are the three boss fights you encounter at the end of the three worlds.  All three of these bad guys are EXTREMELY AWESOME to fight (sorry, I'm in the mood to whip out the big letters!) It is SO much fun shooting fireballs at them.  They also force the player to find a strategy in order to defeat.  You never really came across a boss fight in the previous Spyro game that required a certain strategy.I love the fact that everywhere you go you find LOADS and LOADS of gems and other things.  The levels and worlds in this game are packed with things to find.  Positively PACKED.  A truly awesome game.  The first Spyro the Dragon game was awesome too.  Swimming around really adds more flavor and magic to the game.  Yeah, despite the control problem I mention above, swimming around still manages to be pretty fun.  Of course, there's a lot of running around too.  In fact, there's more running than swimming overall.Pick up Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage.

description: Normally, Nintendo contract players such as Mario, Pikachu, Link, Donkey  Kong, Bowser, and Kirby are generally happy and well-mannered, but inSuper  Smash Bros. Melee, the pleasantries get thrown out and the gloves (except  for Mario's) come off. This update of the N64 favorite features these and other  video game icons in furious, yet utterly absurd fisticuffs that usually make for  a smashing good time. Just make sure you have at least one human opponent to  pound on.Starting off with 14 characters (an additional 11 are waiting to be unlocked),  the game has a pretty standard premise--let Nintendo's stars beat on each other  until the timer runs out. However, a lot of emphasis is put on knocking  opponents off ledges while avoiding the same fate. In typical Nintendo manner,  there are quite a few power-ups to assist you in the melee. The actual combat  isn't as intricate as in other fighting games; however, the ultra-cartoony  layout of the many, many arenas sometimes adds a strategic element not usually  found in similar titles.Super Smash Bros. Melee's strength lays in the mayhem created in  four-player fights. The camera does an excellent job of positioning itself so all  combatants are constantly visible. Also,Meleesports some of the best  visuals seen in a Nintendo product. All the characters are highly detailed, and  the movements of each are smoothly infused with personality. Donkey Kong lumbers  and Princess Peach fights with grace.As the multiplayer mode is the key reason for this game's existence, the  single-player mode is decidedly weak. The game features an adventure mode that plays  somewhat like an old-school, side-scrolling Mario game. Sadly, despite its good  looks, its gameplay is rather uninspired. This game is clearly at its best when  there are two or more players with controllers in their hands.--Mark  BrooksPros:Fantastic graphics and sound keep the action upbeatMany new characters and other goodies to unlockCons:Single-player experience is comparatively weakToo cute for a few folksAdventure mode is boring
reviewText: Another Mario Game that is entertaining and fun for lots of people and great for parties. Nothing that I haven't said before.

summary: "That which starts with a bang ends with a whimper... and what a whimper it is." (SPOILERS)
reviewText: "The Last of Us" is a game that I've been looking forward to playing for the last two years since its announcement in 2011 on SpikeTV's Video Game Awards. Keeping track of its development has been, more or less fun and the anticipation has been part of that fun. But does it live up to the expectations it's lathered itself with overblown advertisement and special editions. Let's find out shall we?THE SET UP:The game opens on a rather mundane note: Civilian life, unaffected by cataclysm. A single father and his daughter exchanging words behind the mask of some really great performances from the actors. The gameplay from there is basically "on-rails"; you're allowed to control the daughter as she wanders about the house searching for her dad, but not much else. The player has no agency in any either case outside of witnessing the collapse of mankind. The situation the daughter neither cared for nor was aware of erupts in a ball fiery chaos that she's otherwise helpless to stop. And, to be honest, despite that set back of losing control of the daughter, the setup is pretty great. It sucks you in and really gets into the atmosphere of the game. Unfortunately, the game never quite hits you the same way ever again and the further you go on, you begin to wonder why the game started the way it did.The narrative switches from the man and his daughter to Joel, a forty some year old survivor with a bad reputation, looking to get even with a fellow smuggler who's double-crossed him and his lady friend. Yet, what starts out as a run of the mill "Get Carter", turns into "The Professional" when an ailing freedom fighter, named Marlene, needs him get someone she cares about to her people clear on the other side of the bombed out United States."The Last of Us" is undoubtedly inspired by the more widely known post-apocalyptic titles that have come out in recent years. Robert Kirkman's "Walking Dead", "I Am Legend" (starring Will Smith) and Cormack McCarthy's "The Road" are the biggest ones, their initial inspiration for their Fungus Monkeys notwithstanding (a BBC documentary on insect fungi that kill and spawn from the dead bodies of their victims). It wants to be the video game equivalent of either one, placing heavy emphasis on "survival at all costs" and the brutality of a society without law and order, etc., etc.In the words of Edward Buck, "You know the music. Time to dance..." And "The Last of Us" walks to the familiar beat of every post-apocalyptic "Not-Zombie" tale that's been told so far. It honestly does nothing with it that wasn't explored in "I Am Legend". And while that's not a bad thing (like, it isn't), the irony of it all is that out of all the inspirations typically cited, "I Am Legend" is probably the biggest thing "The Last of Us" tends to remind me of its desperate need to ape the dark situations and themes I thought were executed out far better in 2009's "The Road". A lot of this, I believe, has a lot to do with the gameplay itself.PROS:VISUALS:First and foremost, it goes without saying that the game is beautiful in the sense that it recaptures the speculative sphere of a world reclaimed by the world that came before: nature. On a standard resolution television it doesn't look like much to write home about; on a glossy HD screen, it really shines. Animals run free and unhindered by the bars of zoos, ruined streets crowded by rusted out cars are cracked with grass and trees that tower over the typical adult human. Things that once mattered before --- computers, bills and jobs --- all sit idle, abandoned by mankind that was driven out into the forests and countryside's by their fellow man turned against them. Said man, now hollowed out vehicles for a mysterious parasite no one knows the origin of, shamble about in the ruins of the cities, looking to infect others or die someplace where they can spread their spores to infect unsuspecting people who wander into their path.Character animation is surprisingly fantastic for something that was largely refined and animated using key frames (a hit or miss method of animation basic emotions that most 3D characters can't capture). It's the little things like subtle emotions expressed by characters, the way the eyes (that still maintain the "dead eye" look from time to time) switch whenever things are spoken or suggested by certain characters. It's pretty entertaining to watch. Similarly the game makes note of the damage you take as player and create some fairly interesting animations to signify Joel or Ellie's injuries (it typically never makes it into the cinematics, unfortunately).GAMEPLAYLike "Remember Me" and "Tomb Raider", "The Last of Us" plays up the illusion of an Open World, but probably allows you to do a little more than either game mentioned allows. It wants you to poke around in every corner possible, but only to an extent: Obviously placed obstacles will pop up more than an invisible wall that slaps you in face with a lack of a signifier. At the same time, however, the game also wants you to be on your toes and be mindful of your surroundings. The task in-and-of-itself is not a hard thing for me. I check-and-double-check my surroundings on the mere basis of either missing an enemy or item that I feel I need to get before I've been shot at so many times that my frustration mounts to the point of gun-and-gun melee attacks.That need to be mindful of sounds, that kick in at the last second to notify you of an enemy presence, resulted in missing items and upgrades. Yet, I can't say that I'm terribly upset about that (I'm not an achievement/collectible hunter). If Naughty's Dog's intention was to make you as tense was possible then they achieved their goal immensely. It doesn't reach "Amnesia: The Dark Descent" levels of terror/tension, but it's pretty good for a game that never claimed to be survival-horror in the first place. In regards to combat, "The Last of Us" gives you as much of an option to take out or slip past your enemies as "Uncharted" does. Slipping past them is always going to be the more favorable option, however, the game does not always give you that option (unfortunately).Another pro in the favor of "The Last of Us" is that the lie that you couldn't control Ellie is revealed as so. At in one point in the game you are allowed to control Ellie. It's probably the one point of the game I enjoyed the most as far as its gameplay is concerned. Avoiding combat is actively encouraged because you are in control of a fourteen year old girl who is neither skilled nor adept at killing anyone unless she can sneak up on them Sam Fisher style and stab them repeatedly with a switchblade. It's also the only time you get to control Ellie (unfortunately)."Listen(ing) Mode" is extremely helpful in regards to counting how many enemies you may encounter in one specific area. There were far too many times where I found myself unable to check my surroundings by merely peeking around the corner, which typically got me spotted (because no one's put "Splinter Cell Conviction's" cover mechanics to good use), so the otherwise superhuman quality of Joel's helped me out a lot.In regards to the companion A.I., it's a hit or miss. Ellie's ability to warn me when I'm about to be jumped from behind is tres helpful; the first time it happened, I was completely surprised that the guy got as close to me as he did. Her ability to toss bricks, however, is a hit or miss. Sometimes she hits her mark, other times, they're far too interested in bum rushing the guy with the gun (me) and the brick misses them. Once you're spotted, she CAN get in trouble, so she's not completely invincible (but it also clashes with what I'll mention in the "Cons" section). Companions do help a great deal when combating enemies, even if they're aim suggests the game still wants YOU to kill all the enemies regardless of their presence."Crafting" allows you to create makeshift weapons to help you in situations wherein traditional weapons may not be readily available to you and it works in spades in melee combat. It's the little details that Naughty Dog puts into the game that makes you appreciate the work put into it.NARRATIVE:The strongest part of the game's narrative is undoubtedly the relationship between Ellie and Joel. It's your atypical "frenemies" turned "surrogate daughter/father" relationship. The two can't stand each other, but tolerate and corporate with each other because they need to survive through to the next day. Circumstances conflate and eventually the trauma of their situation forces the two bond emotionally. The manner in which it is done is nicely paced and comes off more natural than forced and the effort into their relationship is appreciated.PERFORMANCES:The other element of strength are in the performances; pretty much every voice actor involved in this game (from the elusive Jennifer Hale to "Half-Life 2"'s Merle Dandridge/Alyx Vance) is at the top of their game and their performances reflect that. Ashley Johnson is especially great as the fourteen year old Ellie, capturing perfectly the almighty adolescence that makes the even most level headed adult cringe with self-resentment over their behavior of forgotten youth; only, Ellie has no normal outlets in which she can act out, thus making her "rebellion" and misguided youthful energy interesting to watch being channeled in other methods.CONS:VISUALS:The unfortunate side effect for all this detail in the character animation, however, appears to be the same irksome motion blur that attempts to hide clunky motion-capture/animation in the same way Crytek's "Crysis" series does with quick camera turns and oddly reminiscent of George Lucas' attempt to insert the deleted scene of Hans Solo talking things over with a CGI Jabba the Hutt in "A New Hope". It's a minor detail in an otherwise outstanding presentation, but it stands out enough that it bugs me.GAMEPLAY:There's been a great big to do about the A.I. in this game. For the most part, the enemy A.I. is pretty competent. If you fowl up in a stealth segment or somehow get caught by Fungus Monkey, you're going to be killed or end up in a combat situation that you will not benefit from. If you're vice versa, the A.I. is at least polite enough not to notice you and you can get to the next loading screen without incident. However, as I progressed in the game, the A.I. was beginning to remind me of the "Uncharted" with a little more polish added to it. There are a far too many times where the game's A.I. breaks the rules of its universe. There were times where an enemy will notice a fallen comrade, demand to know where you are and fall silent.A few moments later they circle back, spot the fallen comrade again and start threatening you if you don't attack or knock them out. Much like in "Bioshock: Infinite", A.I. controlled companions can and will walk out into the open while enemies are searching for you, but they will not acknowledge his or her presence. It not only breaks the immersion of the game, but signifies no developer has yet to create a perfect balance of "helpful" or "detriment" and will sacrifice any element of the game just to avoid complaints they end up getting anyway. It's actually making me rather appreciative of the A.I. in "Resident Evil 4"; as much as I hated having to save Ashley all the time (shooting her accidentally because she got in the way), you could never fault the A.I. for being dumb as bricks for doing its scripted job and attacking your major weakness.The opposite instance may or may not have been my own fault. Early on the first level of the game, I encounter a pack of Fungus Monkeys. The first couple attempts to get past them in a hail of spore fog was not pleasant. I took a break, calmed myself down and came back to attempt to the section again. I K.O.'ed one and got past the rest without alerting a single one of them. Out in clear daylight inside a room unclouded by spores, I congratulated myself by reading a note I spotted in the room. I'm fooling about with the camera when I notice Tess (my companion for this level) disappear back down the stairs. Out of nowhere, the hideous growls of the enemies came barreling up the stairs to attack me. To say the least, I was baffled. My companion either alerted them (highly doubtful) or the entire scenario was a scripted event where no matter what I did, I was going to be attacked anyway. I'm still trying to figure that out.A personal bother, for me, would be the "Bloaters", infected enemies that toss spores at you. There's a stipulation of the universe that implies that if you inhale any of the spores, you end up infected in a matter of hours or days. Naturally, I would assume, if you encountered these enemies within the gameplay, their spores would kill you in one hit because of their deadliness. Instead, Bloaters are this game's equivalent of "UNCHARTED 2" Heavy Armored enemies (bullet sponges). You waste immeasurable resources on these suckers when you attack them from a distance. Attempting anything else will result in your immediate death. Instead of a spore related death, the Bloaters scratch your face and tear at your jaw "Mortal Kombat" style. Thankfully, they rarely show up within the core gameplay.I don't like how the game never gives you the option to run from a fight once you get caught up in one. More and more often, as the game progresses you are forced into "Uncharted" styled encounters that tip you right off the moment you spot a dozen or so "Chest High Walls" scattered about the environment to hinder your escape and aid only in combat. There is even a bloody sniper segment. A sniper segment in a game where your best choice is run and hope you out pace the enemy or the infected get them first. There's a particular level where you meet a survivor named Bill that throws you into an arena of infected when the scripted "escape" event cuts the player off from the safety as enemies are coming straight for you. I was immediately reminded of the third to final level of "Drake's Fortune" where Nathan is stuck down in a hole fighting Nazi Zombies while Elena procures him a means of escape.Gameplay, overall, is probably my least favorite aspect of this game and that's pretty telling, if anything. More to the point, I experienced the same amount of displeasure in the combat system as I did in "Uncharted 3". Enemies are resilient to the point of annoyance when it comes to guns. Unless you can hit them with a perfect headshot, be prepared to have enemies run at you even as your firing your weapon of choice (sniper-scoped, shotgun, pistol, etc). I had better luck killing enemies with pipes and planks than I have with hand-to-hand combat --- the latter boiling down to the usual quick-time-events and clumsy combat animations and guns.Clickers, Runners and other variety of other Fungus Monkeys are notorious for bullet sponge abilities; and with the added "realism" of your protagonist fumbling with his/her weapon (supposedly), prepare to die in one shot if they so much as breathe one inch from your face. Your best friend will ultimately be a long range weapons, Molotov's and silent take downs --- these are the only aspects of the combat that I actually enjoyed as they are the only aspects that seemed to want to cooperate with me consistently. Naughty Dog has yet to impress me on any level when it comes to gunplay and it's not surprising that it's no different here.And as much I enjoy survival-horror and action-horror, I've never enjoyed what it's done to my fight or flight response. The mind knows its experiencing a vicarious moment; the emotional response itself doesn't. As a result, spending most of my time becoming more frustrated than excited every time I found myself being spotted by an enemy on the SECOND floor whenever I stealth-attacked one of their partner's to death on the level BELOW, inflates my frustration tenfold in tighter situations.As far as platforming is concerned, it's minimal and that's kind of disappointing considering the vistas you could've looked down from climbing up the side of a building. You're biggest channel will be finding either (a): a ladder, (b): a plank, or (c): a dumpster to get to the marginally higher level. And there's actually a little quirk where Joel and Ellie cannot make impossible jumps or even simple jumps that end in scripted events that land them in enemy encounters or the tedious cycle of trial and error.NARRATIVE:VIOLENCE: If this was a film, "The Last of Us" would probably make an unforgettable 90 minutes or two hours, however, as a game, its narrative is needlessly stretched thin by frustrating gameplay that really fails to deliver on the notion of violence being the necessary means to an end. The writers really don't know how to get across the idea of a violence-driven world. McCarthy's "The Road" made it inherently clear that the protagonist used violence when it was necessary and it was usually in the name of protecting his son. He never popped his gun off because someone told him to step off or get beat senseless. The violence was driven by necessity. In "The Last of Us", the violence depicted in the game never feels necessary so much as it feels like a trigger to incite gameplay because the story of "The Last of Us" is being presented as a game where violence is commonplace, but never necessary. The so-called survivors that the player encounters in the game come off as hired thugs from "Splinter Cell" and "Batman: Arkham City". There is never an instance that these characters are acting out of violence because it is necessary and they can benefit from it, but because they can. When you attack these men there's never an instance wherein you feel like you're about to kill a person driven to the edge of sanity, like Joel supposedly was, but just another hired gun for an invisible antagonist that never appears in the game.Their position as body counts for the player to pick off because they are "Enemy A.I." renders their status as fellow survivors that are forced to survive in otherwise unsavory means null because we're never given the opportunity or chance to see them as anything other than "obstacles". The architecture of the game clearly labels them as enemies and thus needs them characterized as such. Violence is also incited situations wherein it should've have been allowed to be avoided. But because this is a video game, we can't go without fighting mooks so the game forces you into situations wherein the player must fight with limited resources or suffer the deaths of a thousand deaths if he/she attempts to do otherwise.When I think back on "The Walking Dead", game always made you hyper aware of what you were doing and the possible consequences that would follow had you taken that course of action. From the people you meet twisted by a zombie apocalypse, to the very final moments of the game wherein you meet another person pushed to the brink of sanity; the violence that was always present in this game impacted the narrative and characters as well as the gameplay. And every time you reached the end of an episode, you thought about the things you did, be it triggered by violence done to others or yourself.Here, violence is typically incited by the gameplay and not the story. In order to get you familiar with the controls, the gameplay incites a pointless moment of antagonism between Tess (my companion) and a character that doesn't physically attack her but threatens her by way of telling her to get lost. Her very words "Forget this" and the gunshot to the man's head is there simply to get the player involved in the violence that it incites because it's a game, but it does not drive the narrative in the same sense. I spent more time scowling at my screen and wondering why that had to happen than I did thinking about statements that Naughty Dog wanted to use with violence in their narrative. Basically, it's another case of action vs. story.CHARACTER: The heart of "The Last of Us" is the relationship between Joel and Ellie; it's clear on that point that the biggest amount of work into that particular aspect of the story. People are paramount in the narrative of the game and it shows. Survivors come and go like guest stars in a television series, and really, beyond Ellie, it's the minor characters I found myself the most interested in. It's also usually where a game like this basically loses me because of its absolute disregard for said characters.As a Person of Color it still bothers me that post-apocalyptic narratives are presented as overwhelmingly white. As a Person of Color, I hate that in the first level I'm astonished to see as many Non-Playable Characters of Color appearing oddly out of nowhere, shooting the breeze, if only to eventually dissuade controversial discussion over the next instance of pointless violence towards a stereotyped POC that verbally threatens a white woman (it literally embodies "The Black Guy Dies First"). As a woman, I'm bothered by the fact that for a game that purported to be a game about a girl and how she bonds with an older man on a perilous journey, that I have to play from the perspective of the so-called man with no morality. It essentially defeats the purpose of a female-driven narrative and colors my opinion on how the writer is able to even get across that Joel is man without compromise or sympathy with one exception because of the world he lives in now. How I choose to play as Joel flies in the face of how they want to portray him. And the more I think about this, the more I think Joel would've benefited from being a Non-Playable Character with the player in control of Ellie.Sarah becomes irrelevant in the spectrum of what makes Joel who he is. Sarah's death adds nothing to the narrative of Joel like the situation of the world ending does. There's one confrontation between Joel and Ellie over Sarah that goes nowhere because its forgiven the next instant. The intro begins to feel like a game that started but never began. Sure he's broken because of his daughter's death, but they make it clear the world and not her, made him decide that he was to become a stone-cold killer. And that thematic never really comes into true play until the final stretch of the game.There is a great deal about this aspect of "The Last of Us" drama that feels contrived. Minor characters that accompany you from time-to-time are killed off to remind the player that this is not a happy world and that this story is full of angst. As a result, emotional investment in complex minority characters like Marlene, Tess, Sarah, Sam and Henry is wasted endeavor as considering their position in a post-apocalyptic narrative. They are all sacrificed in the name of boosting white and male drama. Henry and Sam are literally used as mirrors for what WON'T happen to Ellie and Joel (because their the protagonists). Tess' demise feels like they ran out of ideas for the character and offed her because they didn't want a third wheel tagging along. Sarah's death, while undeniably heartbreaking, begins to feel like a hollow event made up of shock value. It even hits a home run with the "Bury Your Gays" trope with one particular character you work alongside with early on. Does it work? For the most part, yes and its because they actually allow him to be a PERSON shaped by the same circumstances as everyone else. Yet, he isn't allowed to be in the same sense that the thing that would really oust him for being overtly Gay in an industry that shuns homosexuality, is killed, hence the aforementioned trope. Watching these characters drop off one-by-one was like watching "Buffy the Vampire Slayer"'s "Becoming, Part One" and "Seeing Red" over and over again. It didn't matter that Kendra (the Slayer of Color) or Tara (Willow's lover since S4) were characters with potential and could be used in another manner that didn't end with "death".They had to die because Buffy and Willow needed feel responsible for their deaths and the same formula is used in "The Last of Us". Other character's stake in the narrative doesn't matter outside of their relationship to Joel and Ellie. Every minority death that occurs is all in the name of boosting the white and male protagonist's drama. As a minority, I'm quite tired seeing POC, Gay and female characters used a sacrificial lambs for that type of drama. Heck, the narrative eventually removes Ellie from any sort of mental or physical agency near the end of the game, all to pull some hackneyed ending that is far too reminiscent every "Uncharted" ending ever. However, instead of zombies, immortal tree sap and psychotropic water, it feels more like the theatrical tending of "I Am Legend". Because of the title, the writer's felt the need to come up with something that reflected it instead of, I dunno, creating something just a little smarter than what was given.The sticking point of the narrative is that Ellie is immune to the parasite that turns people into infected: She is literally the "Omega Man", but the story doesn't make anything out of it. It actually does a great job of avoiding characterizing Ellie as the second coming of Christ. But, I also think that's where it falters. At some point, the story seems to forget about Ellie's infection in the hail of Uncharted gunplay and tedious stealth sections. It becomes less about the cure and more about her relationship with Joel. So, the final few hours feel like something that pulled right out of their rear ends. Ellie is removed from the largest part of the narrative and essentially robbed of all agency. When it comes to the BIGGEST PART of the narrative where HER CHOICES may have impacted the path of the story, she's knocked out. And it's all in order to tent-pole the male ego's need to rescue a young woman with no say in her fate. No say in a situation she would arguably went along with the plan, considering her determination to complete her mission."The Last of Us" becomes less about Ellie bonding with a deplorable man and more about a deplorable man's selfishness mattering more than the possibility of arming mankind with some type of internal defense against a fungus. The irony of it all is that you know Ellie knows that he is lying. Most will undoubtedly enjoy it because they get to keep both characters alive and intact and I can respect that (who wants to see anyone die, really?). For me, it the ending feels too-self aware and proactive of a choice that wanted avoid the "obvious" ending in universe that implies no one has "Plot Armor" (and everyone dies). Not because it was right, but because they didn't want to come off as "obvious".Overall, "The Last of Us", while not horrible, is lacking focus. The game introduced some great ideas with its gameplay and mechanics, but the need to fall back on traditional TPS mechanics and finicky A.I. ruins the balance they were aiming for. The story of Ellie and Joel is a moving one, but it a story better suited for a movie as the gameplay does nothing to add or enhance that relationship. Minor characters are great, but sorely wasted and mistreated in a game that doesn't have the attention span to focus on anyone who isn't Ellie and Joel. Violence feels more geared to the necessity of gameplay and never the story itself. "The Last of Us" is a movie that could be better suited with avoiding the atypical narrative tropes it used here. To say the least, I'm sorely disappointed with the final product. especially whenever I think back on the fantastic job Telltale did with "The Walking Dead". [a 3 out of 5].Also: Love it that my review got a 0 out of 01 the second it pops up on the page. Someone's fingers must be pruny from prolonged water exposure :D.

summary: Hits every emotion and paints a frightening post-apocalyptic "what-if"
reviewText: What scares you more in a zombie filled world? The mindless zombies that'll indiscriminately eat anything in sight or the remaining humans who believe in "survival of the fittest"? Personally the human bandits frightened me the most. Naughty Dog did a phenomenal job of crafting all the villains and soldiers who hunt you ruthlessly because we all knew what to expect from the zombies already. The visuals were easily the best of any current generation console game. The details were off the charts in this game. The lush environments and the item crafting really stood out. Unlike previous titles, ND basically gave you scraps throughout the game to make equipment. Isn't that what you should expect if the world went to hell? There wasn't and there shouldn't be treasure chests filled with gear and ammo for you. Every bullet counts because on hard difficulty there is barely anything for you to craft with. I loved the visuals and the premise of the game but the two stars of the game, Ellie and Joel stand apart from the rest. The maturation of Ellie into a hardened and intelligent young woman resembled that of an award-winning novel. When the cards are dealt, you play them as they are and you don't have a say. She deals with lost loved one after another, killing a person for the first time, and carrying the weight of potentially being a cure for humanity. She straddles the line between bending and breaking but she never does break.Joel on the other hand, has to carry the guilt of losing his daughter at the beginning of the apocalypse for decades before. He wants nothing to do with Ellie at first for obvious reasons, he couldn't save his own daughter how could he be expected to protect another? It wasn't a coincidence that his daughter is roughly the same age as Ellie. Joel wants to bury his past but as he tries to make amends with himself. In the end, Ellie gives him the chance to do what he couldn't 20 years before which is save her from the elements and the situation. His relentlessness towards zombies and bandits is chilling at times. This is a man unleashing years of pain and anger with every kill he makes.Joel and Ellie are without a doubt, the two best characters fleshed out in a game that I can remember. If you merely add the game play and graphics without the leading characters, this game would have been a 8 or 9 out of a 10. But Naughty Dog spent the time and effort to craft an amazing story held together with two flawed, and very human, characters. They take what is given to them because that is all they can do. There is no knight in shining armor to save them. They only have each other.Anybody who thought the story and game were boring needed to be evaluated. I can only assume that the 1 star reviews were written by kids who enjoy watching cartoon network or WWE all day and think those are more entertaining some how.

summary: Absolutely amazing experience from start to finish!!!
reviewText: I wasn't planning to buy this game at first, and having just finished Tomb Raider, which I thoroughly enjoyed, I was unsure if this game could stand up to the numerous positive reviews posted. I decided to give it a try, and was simply amazed! The ending was really surprisingly emotional and thought-provoking, which stands out from 99% of the games in the market today in my opinion.The visuals, the plot, the gun play, the level design, are all fantastically done, and the sheer variety of situations was just plain awesome. I must rate this as one of the best games I've played in the past several years. The closest description would be Uncharted + Tomb Raider with heavy emphasis on stealth. description: Neo-Paris. 2084.Personal memories can now be digitized, bought, sold and traded. The last remnants of privacy and intimacy have been swept away in what appears to be a logical progression of the explosive growth of social networks at the beginning of the 21st century. The citizens themselves have accepted this surveillance society in exchange for the comfort only smart technology can provide. This memory economy gives immense power over society to just a handful of people.Remember Me is a 3rd person action adventure where players take on the role of Nilin, a former elite memory hunter with the ability to break into people's minds and steal or even alter their memories. The authorities, fearful of her knowledge and capabilities have arrested Nilin and wiped her memory clean. After her escape from prison, Nilin sets out on a mission to recover her identity, helped by her last and only friend. This search for her past leads to her being hunted by the very people that created this surveillance society.
